授業目的: The purpose of this class is for students to understand why US economy has been generating innovation which is a driving force of economy.
到達目標: Students will be able to understand the followings: (1) how US corporate strategies have generated innovation, (2) how US institution has been helpful for innovation, and (3) whether or not US government policies have promoted innovation.
授業方法: Textbook 1 will be covered by lectures by the instructor and Textbook 2 will be covered by students' presentation.

第1回: Introduction to Innovation: defition of innovation as well as innovation and institution.
第2回: Innovation Theories: microeconomic theory and market failures.
第3回: Corporation Strategies for Innovation: views from technology managemen and corporate governance.
第4回: Roles of Patents and Standards: a review of pro-patent policy in the US.
第5回: Competition Policy and Innovation: a review of controvery regarding the Schumpeter Hypothesis.
第6回: Motivations for Scholars: rewards and recognition for scholars.
第7回: Financial Incentives: patents and royalty revenues for professors.
第8回: Collaboration among Scholars: production of research.
第9回: Funding for Research: the role of government funding for academic research.
第10回: Market for Scientists and Engineers: supply and demand of scientists and engineers.
第11回: Foreign Borns scientists: the roles of immigration policy.
第12回: Science and Economic Growth: a view of macroeconomics.
第13回: Discussing tne topics of the entire textbook 2.
Preparing the book review of textbook 2 (4 hours)
第14回: Student Presentation of his/her own research paper.
トピック.授業外学習2: Students should read the assigned chapters of textbook 1 and should be prepared for presentations based on the content of textbook 2. Students are encouraged to start reading textbook 2 from the beginning of the semester.

Textbook 2: Pual Stephan (2012) How Economics Shapes Science, Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press. Paperback Edition (2015)（ISBN:978-06-74088160 pap.)Students should buy both textbooks by themselves.
